title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent In Boston

content.rendered:
“Congratulations!” you just received an email to confirm your acceptance into that college! Or is it a position at that firm Boston? Or are you relocating because you are in need of a change of environment. No matter your reason for searching for rooms for rent in Boston, you made an excellent choice. Here’s why.

Related: 15 Best Things To Do In Boston

Getting to know Boston

Boston aka the “Beantown” has 23 distinct neighborhoods. Each district has its own distinctive characteristics such as the vibrant college community in Allston, and the rich history that dominates the streets of Beacon Hill. The region is renowned for its excellent healthcare facilities, with Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women’s Hospital making it to the U.S. News and World Report’s Top 20 Best Hospitals in the country. Boston is also known for its baked beans and New England clam chowder which is responsible for its nickname, although it has a diverse culinary culture and cuisine. Getting excited? Well here’s what to consider when searching for rooms for rent in Boston.

Finding rooms for rent in Boston

Before moving into one of the rooms for rent in Boston, it is important to sit down and prepare a budget for living expenses, parking and commuting expenses, and moving costs. Boston’s housing and rental prices are generally more expensive than those in many other parts of the U.S. The decision to move to a new location can also have an impact on housing costs and commute costs. Moving at a particular time of year can have an impact on your inventory.

Most people move to Boston in September because it is home to a large number of students. That way you can find a roommate to share your room. You can use a roommate finder Boston for ease.

Related: Rules To Set In Apartments For Rent With Roommates

Find Rooms for Rent in Boston

Top neighborhoods in Boston

  • Beacon Hill: This area is considered one of the most beautiful neighborhoods in the city, with historic row houses and cobblestone roads that are lit with gas street lamps. Both residents and tourists are expected to venture around here, most searching for rooms for rent in Boston MA.
  • South Boston: Also known as Southie, this neighborhood that was historically populated predominantly by Irish Catholics has become increasingly popular with younger families and graduates. Waterfront access and a large number of new developments have contributed to the increase in rent prices.
  • Back Bay: This city neighborhood is reputed to house more affluent families and members of the community. An additional few hundred dollars may be necessary for rent here in comparison to other parts of the city. Arguably the most expensive place to get rooms for rent in Boston MA.

Average rent in Boston

Housing costs, utility bills, and healthcare make up the three main factors that are significantly higher than the national average cost of living. Boston is home to limited housing options for middle-class families, resulting in a lack of supply and a consequent increase in housing costs.

University life in Boston

With over 125 school sites in the Boston Public School system, you are sure to find a program that is suitable for your child. One area where the Boston metropolis stands out is in the university setting. Some consider Boston a college town and a center of higher learning, which makes sense since it has so many colleges packed into a small geographical area. One of the benefits of being a student in Boston is that coeds can take advantage of subsidized housing, where they can utilize lower rentals than are typically found in neighborhoods that are more popular. Some of the popular colleges and universities include:

  • Boston University
  • MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
  • Harvard
  • Tufts University
  • Boston College

How transit-friendly is Boston

One word of advice: get a quality GPS app for your phone for navigating the city. There are numerous one-way streets, roundabouts, and dead-ends in the city, which can give you a serious case of road rage.

Walkability

Boston received an overall walkability score of 82 and was ranked third in terms of walkability among all large cities.

Roads/Traffic

Boston suffers from the worst traffic congestion in North America, behind only Mexico City, and the worst by far in the United States in 2019. Additionally, Boston drivers lost an estimated 149 hours that year due to traffic.

Taxis

In the event, you need to arrange for a taxi to pick up you in a residential area, here are the major cab companies that are available to you:  Boston Logan Taxi Cab, Boston Cab, ITOA, Metro Cab, and 617TaxiCab.

Public Transportation

Boston may be known as “America’s Walking City,” but it also boasts a reliable and efficient transportation system that comprises commuter rails, intercity/interstate buses, even private charter buses.

Airports

Boston Logan International Airport (BOS) is Boston’s major airport.

Cycle friendly

Blue bikes is your bike share system. There are over 100 stations and over 1,000 bikes available throughout the areas of Boston, Cambridge, Brookline, and Somerville.

Related: 5 Reasons to Move to Boston

Restaurants in Boston

Boston baked beans, the New England clam chowder, and lobster rolls are some of the best foods in the area. However, Boston has a strong global culture thanks to a large immigrant population, with a great array of international foods. The Ultimate Boston Neighborhood Restaurant Guide is filled with delicious culinary delights that are available in every part of the city—Asian specialties in Chinatown, Italian food in the North End, Caribbean dishes in Roxbury, seafood near the harbor, and many more.

Sports in Boston

Bostonians are passionate about their sports teams. There are a lot of sports teams to cheer for in Boston including the Boston Celtics and Boston Bruins at TD Garden, New England Patriots at the Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, and Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park. An enthusiastic crowd will always assemble to support the team of the city. Boston also has a professional soccer team, The New England Revolution, which competes in the Eastern Conference of Major League Soccer.
